author: agemanning
content:
<@!604062686623432740> - Discv5 doesn't really have a peer count. Its UDP and peers come and go quite rapidly. We cap the number of sessions that get established to 1000. But these are just handshakes and nodes from all networks in the DHT will add to this. 
Our PeerDb are tcp connections with nodes are are live and active.

author: jonny.derp
content:
> <@!604062686623432740> - Discv5 doesn't really have a peer count. Its UDP and peers come and go quite rapidly. We cap the number of sessions that get established to 1000. But these are just handshakes and nodes from all networks in the DHT will add to this. 
> Our PeerDb are tcp connections with nodes are are live and active.
<@498009160982724610> 

Ok ya. Makes sense hearing you explain it.  I  was thinking of your connected_peers() method in discv5 and (incorrectly) wondering if that peer count was being reported.

https://github.com/sigp/discv5/blob/a653fc1a3bade8ed96bff152e73ee5beb64daf86/src/discv5.rs#L255

author: nishant0
content: For us our peer count will show the current active and live peers, so they should be accurate. Is there any reason you think the numbers are inflated ?

author: agemanning
content:
Oh yeah. I had that there as a useful tool to see which peers are active in the local routing table. 
Again those peers can be on any network and are unfiltered. We don't report this in lighthouse in any form

author: jonny.derp
content:
> For us our peer count will show the current active and live peers, so they should be accurate. Is there any reason you think the numbers are inflated ?
<@476250636548308992> 

Ya I've crawled Altona a couple of times in the past day or so and found a lot of enrs that I couldn't contact.  At one point something like 54 peers, but only 25 were contactable.  I only let the crawler run for 5 or 10 minutes, but if there are really nodes with 243 peers...I should be finding a lot more, a lot faster.

content: Good bye that time my dev boards will be done compiling all the clients. I want to try running validators on more exotic architectures eg. NetBSD/ARM, OpenBSD etc.

author: prestonvanloon
content:
Update: user claims alpha.14 didnâ€™t fix their issue. We still donâ€™t know what their issue is because the only shared it privately with one person on the team who is asleep right now. They claim to be still syncing and the issue is after sync. They have sent me their keystore.

The options are:
- wait and see
- run the validator for them (could end up getting slashed)
- wait until their active validators are eligible for voluntary exit 
- produce slashable conditions for all of their active validators

author: prestonvanloon
content: Depending on urgency, we can choose from the above

author: ajsutton
content: The point of a testnet is to see what breaks.  We've got a lot of fixes that have gone into Teku to improve our handling of non-finalization which we've backported and tested on Witti but it's actually quite useful to have more users test it out.  I've already put up a PR to tune one setting.

author: ajsutton
content: So I wouldn't panic about it - take the time you need to work through the issue with them so Prysm gets whatever fixes wind up being required.  Probably worth getting them to exit a bunch of validators once it's working though so they don't own the whole network.  Or we all register a heap more validators and ramp up the size of Altona.

author: nishant0
content: <@399309815517544451> i shared the correct solution with them, so just waiting for them to apply it

author: prestonvanloon
content: I think they have signed off for the night
